This review will be short to avoid spoilers.

Medusa's Labyrinth is one of the best horror games I have played in a long time and the idea behind it is awesome.

This game is set in ancient Greece where you explore a labyrinth with an ancient evil that chases you.

To help you find the exit you have a torch and a bow. The torch is used to go through tunnels that are too dark and I'm not sure what the bow is used for. I at first thought it was used for distractions, but I couldn't get it to work, so I have no idea what the bow does.

The atmosphere is beyond amazing and the dimly lit tunnels are incredibly creepy.

The problems with the game that it's incredibly short, from what I remember reading this game is a part of something larger and I can't wait to see what the studio is going to do in the future.

Overall it's free so what do you have to lose ?

Final Rating:
7/10 - Play It

reviewText:
The first thing you immediately notice when starting up Guru Games' Medusa's Labyrinth is how stunningly beautiful this game looks. Ultra settings can require a lot of resources from your end (I am not sure if this is a matter of optimisation, though) - this is something that usually only AAA games do.

Once you finished your marvelling just outside the ancient temple your journey continues within. The admiration stops here and is replaced by the constant fear of something (perhaps a Medusa?) lurking somewhere in the ancient corridors. Using headphones or turning the volume up a lot is a must here; a torchlight can certainly ease the terror but your bow with only 3 arrows will not do so, at all.

Then, when you finally know who you're up against, a chase ensues and continues until it abruptly ends. And this is the only issue Medusa's Labyrinth has - it is unfinished. The 60-minute or so story seems to be polished enough but how amazing it would be to see the story through till its very end. Especially since the notes scattered across the temple give you some background information but only to increase your curiosity and desire for more.

I do not know that of all the 150,000 downloads how many players purchased the DLC content to provide financial support but I sincerely hope Guru Games will get it so that they create a 10-hour long campaign to finish the tale.

So, seeing as how it was a free game, I'm going to recommend it. I hope the developers read these, because I'm going to make some suggestions. First, this game has a lot of potential. It's beautiful once you get inside, but honestly, the first half of the game I was LOOKING for the thing I was suppose to be afraid of. When I finally found it, I was left wanting more from it. It seemed to have no real personality, and I feel that if you gave it one, it would be much more monsterous.

Second, I had no real connection to who I was or what role I played. I had an idea, and I understand this is an unfinished game, but there was a story that could have been told that made me WANT to be there and have a connection. I feel that it fell flat at that part. I had zero connection to the character, and I felt I was simply walking a linear path the entire game.

Third, I would back this game for an ending. I'm curious to how much depth you could get out of this game, and seeing as how you said this was an incomplete part, I bet the story could be amazing. The constant heart beat was rather annoying, and to me didn't really serve a purpose on top of the distorted view. I would rather have one or the other myself.

I would recommend this game if you have a bit of time to spare since it's absolutely free, and if the game builds more, well, that's just an added bonus.

reviewText:
Medusa's Labyrinth is a common sort of horror game. It follows the same rules as many other first person indie horror games, which to me have quickly become the new indie platformer due to how easy it is to produce them compared to other games, and how easy it is to get the intented effect.

The setting is unique amongst this subgenre, but it didn't surprise me in the slightest. I felt it was going to be a minotaur maze and it was, minus the maze part. The level design is not like a labyrinth or maze, it is more like a single, tangled up noodle. There is a set linear path through this game and you are not likely to ever get lost. This is also a good thing as it means despite being set in underground catacombs, each room is made visually distinct enough to not get stale.

Most corridors are blocked with debris and there isn't much opportunity to get lost. With the intent of all these typical indie horror games being to instill an in the moment" kind of fright
date: you would think that the prospect of getting lost in a maze would be a primary mechanical focus of this game. Personally I feel something like that would work in this game's favor.\n\nLike I said it is a common first person indie horror game. You know exactly what you are getting into. The main draw comes not from fluff or story
recommended:
but from the design of the AI creature you are intended to feel scared of.
The AI creature in this particular indie horror game works mechanically identical to any other. It is a humanoid creature with small patrol routes that has AI that can be easily exploited for an easy kill. I guess the most unique part of this indie horror game is the fact you can kill the AI creature. It has funny ragdolls a bit like a souls game.

Medusa's Labyrinth is a throwaway title that relies heavily on scripted triggers and the player to follow a linear path. It has lovely landscapes (just don't look at anything up close)

reviewText:
Half an hour long stealth horror game. It's something like demo/prototype, student project or something. Take it or leave it.

It's built on UE4 so it looks like any other idie UE4 game. Flashy colours and simplistic design.
The game has it's build up and tension. Which is shattered by the very first encounter with it's absolutely awful AI. It doesn't hear you, but it sees you through walls. Can't catch you anyway if you move along safe areas. Fortunately there is only two encounters so there's that. Yeah, the game is pretty low on horror part. And on every other part. There is some gimmick mechanics like torches and igniting lights and there is even bow to shot that one rope. Sound design doesn't stand out from it's gameplay and visuals - works, doesn't stand out. But music really sets the tone and compliments the game atmosphere. The best part of the game is it's setting as Greek mythology is severely underused in games.

In conclusion: nothing to write home about. It's half an hour long game with 10 minutes of tension. Well, it's free because it can't justify any price, but still it's free. Download and play it, 10 minutes of fun for free is often more than other paid products can offer.

reviewText:
The overall quality of the game was extremely low, things such as lighting and footsteps did not seems realistic at all. The level design of the game was boring, I was going in hoping for something much more interesting due to being a fan of greek mythology but most of the tunnel system was bare of any interesting details and is simply boring hallways connecting mostly empty rooms.

The main gameplay elements are not fleshed out very well, you are given a bow but the only use of it is to shoot a rope 10sec after you're given it and it's quickly forgotten. The active inventory for the game was pretty neat, as you could look into your quiver to see arrows and torches left rather than an inventory screen - but since arrows and torches were mostly useless so was this feature. The game has this stupid thing where your screen pulses every time a monster might be near and it throws you out of the moment completely, making the horror side of the game mostly a joke as it is just not scary.

The writing and story of the game are not really good either, a kind of interesting story is told left in notes throughout the labyrinth but not something that hasn't been seen before in dozens of better examples, and the notes themselves are mostly poorly written. The plot lacks a solid ending and it cut off in a very cheap feeling way.

For a free 30min game it's not horrible, just not really worth spending your time on.

reviewText: I'm Scared

Medusa's labyrinth is a first person stealth game set in mythical ancient greece, that is clunky, short and slow to get going. Having said that....when it does get going it's pretty effective at being intense, and making the most of a basic setup.

It's only an hour or so long, and is more of a proof of concept than a full on game  - which I think the creators have admitted to (?) and it's free anyway.....If they do make a complete go of this they've certainly got a lot right here.

It sets up a foreboding atmosphere in the first half an hour, as you wander deeper into a very dark temple / catacomb area, with little happening except for a few nicely paced jumpy events to unsettle you. There's some well written notes that you find lying about that build up the experience quite well as they give a bit of backstory, and lessen what would otherwise be a little bit boring.

But you'll soon find out that the place you're in isn't deserted, and the occupants are none too friendly, or human for that matter.....You have a torch and a bow, though these don't help much as (a) the bow is only for distracting enemy, and (b) torches burn out, and also even with the brightness turned upto full this is a dark game with your light not extending very far. It also gives away your position, meaning you have to chuck it away and move through the darkness if you want to avoid getting your head bashed in.

It's at this point that the slow build up really pays off, and the last half of the game" is fairly nerve wracking.

I think they've got the atmosphere nailed

Medusa's Labyrinth
DISCLAIMER: I have nothing to do with the developers of the game and have in no way shape or form ever had contact with them before writing this review.

My youtube video about the game:  https://youtu.be/ihE9MWYVjn8

Gameplay
The game was very enjoyable to play and the framerate was great. At first I was a bit afraid of the game genre cause I am not an avid horror gamer. Most of the time I don't even like the horror genre that much, but even then it managed to intrigue me.
There is a DLC to the game you can buy for  5$ but it does NOT include extra in game material just some concept art and is merely a way to support the developers.
AI seemed to be on point to, the enemy was quite difficult to dodge and did a good job looking for me. I tried using my bow to shoot the enemy but it did not really do anything. It just made him angry and run at me so I don't really see the point of the bow.
I did not finish the game till the end, however I have read that it is not a very long game. I personally have no problem with that and you shouldn't either keeping in mind this is a FREE game.

Storyline
There is a storyline to the game but it is nothing special. There is no voice acting as far as I can tell but there is a story boing told with the help of notes you can find. You see some time was put into these because they use a lot of old english words which help you stay immersed into the game and really make you feel like you are in ancient greece again.

Looks And Music
B-E-A-Utiful, the game looks stunning for a free game and the music is just right there when needed. There is a lot of ambient noice keeping me on the edge of my seat ready to get me scared again. I was very much impressed with the soundwork, great job guys! I am amazed!

Verdict
This game did a lot of things right and will give you a good scare for the price of nothing. I like it and I am certain you will not regret it if you install this game. Don't expect crazy storyline or a triple A title, it is just a free game you can play for fun.
If you are looking for some free scary horror fun on steam just dowload this game, you loose nothing and will definitely put a smile on the developer's face.

TL;DR

positives
- good graphics and optimization
- free
- good AI
- great scary vibe, darkness
- sound was amazing

negatives
- story line is nothing to write home about
- your bow does allmost nothing
- there is DLC but it has no extra game material

The fact that this game is completely free detracts from any complaints about polish and other minor issues. It looks great and draws from very interesting, and from a video game design sense, fresh ideas/mythology that will keep you reading through the short gameplay.\n\nCan't hurt to give it a try!

Starting the game it already feels extremely weird in the main menu, seeing the counter drop to about 30 fps as I play on high, not even ultra, as the lighting effects draw all the frames.

Theres no advanced graphics options. Theres no way to go fullscreen. Windowed mode does what it wants.

But I decided to give it a try anyways and start.. Well, getting sick of the low visuals which I still prefer over a slideshow, I give it a try as the windowed mode decides to go weirdly all over my screen.

Welp, gameplay was a bit weird and didnt feel good either and the options and optimisation were horrendeous.

4GB for 40 minutes of boring running around.
The story bits you gather are ok I guess, but the font it's written in takes away from the immersion.
The monster is not at all scary. It's mostly just annoying because even tho you have a bow & arrow you can't shoot the monster. You only use the bow once to cut a rope, and that was it.
I kept waiting for something to happen until I saw the credits after 40 minutes (10 of which where trying to find out how to kill the monster, but nothings seems to work).

The sound in this is amazing, played by myself in the dark like every other horror game and I must say it was pretty tense.

However, like other reviews have stated, the story is pretty short!

Tip: Press tab to bring up your inventory and save torches for later - something I didn't realise at first!

7/10
